results.title: Antenna installation
results.creator_credit: McGraw-Hill Films and Loucks and Norling Studios
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic Television”.
Part of a series of films designed for screening to students studying television principles and servicing. This episode uses animation and live action to illustrate directivity and the characteristics of the basic dipole antenna, and to show a typical step-by-step installation of an antenna. It includes demonstrations to illustrate a chimney strap mounting, the use of stand-offs, the use of the Rawl drill, and the installation of the lightning arrester and ground rod. NB: This film may be considered out-of-date but useful for basic instructions (11/97).

results.title: Antarctica: the unowned land
results.brief_description: Provides an introduction to Antarctica showing landforms, ice and animal life such as penguins and whales. Briefly touches on the impact of humans in the area. The program also spends some time studying the animal life in the Falkland Islands. No other credits available.

results.title: Antarctica: physical geography
results.creator_credit: Stafford Garner, National Geographic Society and Chris McCullough
results.brief_description: Detailed documentary on the world’s coldest continent, Antarctica. Discusses a variety of topics including the geography and climate of the continent, the marine life it supports, and how this “polar desert” can be viewed as a barometer of earth’s wellbeing, both past and present. Includes archival footage of Australian explorer Douglas Mawson’s expedition to Antarctica in 1912.

results.title: Antarctica 1948
results.brief_description: A record of the operations of the Australian National Antarctic Research Expedition, from November 1947 until April 1948. Meteorologists, metallurgists, geologists, zoologists and biologists took part in the expedition. A meteorological station was established on Heard Island, south of Fremantle. Another party set out for Macquarie Island, with the intention of landing on the mainland of Antarctica, to carry out a geological survey, but pack ice prevented this, making it impossible for the party to land.

results.title: Antarctica (Episode 3)
results.brief_description: Looks at the heroic early exploration of the continent and the ensuing exploitation if its wildlife, the flora and fauna, and the scientific studies beng carried out in Antarctica today. The possibility of future utilization of Antarctica’s mineral wealth is discusssed.

results.title: Antarctica
results.creator_credit: Clayton J. Edwards, Image Associates and Bastian Wimmer
results.brief_description: Examines some of the significant research projects being carried out in Antartica under the auspices of the National Science Foundation. Shows how these projects relate to worldwide concerns and emphasizes the cooperation of American scientists with those from other countries.

results.title: Antarctica
results.creator_credit: Fuji Telecasting, Gakken Company, Kurahoa Productions, Masaru Kakutani, Koretsugu Kurahara and Koreyoshi Kurahara
results.brief_description: The year is 1958. The men of the first Japanese Antarctic expedition are expecting to be relieved by another party on board the ice breaker ‘Soya’. A fierce blizzard erupts and the ‘Soya’ is unable to reach base camp. A small plane is used to ferry the men of the first expedition back to the ice breaker. The men, believing the second party to be on its way, left behind fifteen sled dogs which were chained to posts embedded in ice. This is the incredible true story of these sled dogs and their struggle to survive an Antarctic winter. Narrated by Robert Wagner and music by Vangelis.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Fuji Telecasting, Gakken Company, Kurahoa Productions, Masaru Kakutani, Koretsugu Kurahara and Koreyoshi Kurahara

results.title: Antarctica
results.brief_description: New Zealand’s proximity to Antarctica has led to an active involvement in its scientific exploration since the late 50s. Antarctica has seen two historical periods- the early age of exploration and the age of scientific exploration. With the scarcity of natural resources will the next age be that of exploitation

results.title: Antarctica
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Quantum”.
Explains Australia’s involvement in the setting up of research bases in Antarctica. Major research at the bases is looked at. Shows auroras and cosmic rays research at Mawson as well as Glaciology studies at Casey and animal studies at Davis.
